The United States of America  
advanced version 
1 Geography 
The USA lies in the northern Hemisphere, it borders with Canada in the north and with 
Mexico in the south. Interesting is that the US -Mexico border is the longest guarded border in 
the world. The Atlantic Ocean is on the eastern coast of the USA and the Pacific Ocean is on 
the west. The USA is the 4th biggest country in the world after Russia, Canada and China. 
 
The longest rivers are Mississippi, Missouri and Colorado. There are several great like s in the 
northern border with Canada and their names are Lake Superior, Ontario, Michigan, Huron 
and Erie. Niagara falls are between lakes Ontario and Erie. The highest mountain is Mt. Mac 
Kinley with its 6194 meters. One of the hottest places in the world  and the lowest in the USA 
is Death Valley which lies in Nevada desert. Thanks to its vast area the USA is a country with 
many climates, from arctic climate in Alaska to subtropical climate in southern states of USA 
(eg. California, New Mexico, Nevada, Texas). 
2 History 
The new continent was discovered in 1492 by Christopher Columbus who sailed from Spain 
to find a new way ho w to get to India. At first he thought he is in India , so he called the 
natives “Indians”. These native tribes were no t developed as Eur opean nations and they were 
living mostly from agriculture, hunting and fishing. Since the discovery of the new continent 
Europeans colonized the whole area of the USA which belonged later to the British Empire.   
 
In 1773 a group of patriots dressed like Indians threw British tea into the sea in the harbo ur as 
a protest of new taxation on sug ar, coffee and textile in the British colony. In 1776 the USA 
declared independence and the war between the United Kingdom of Great Britain and 
American colonists started. The Americans won the war of independence in 1783. 
 
Another import war in the USA history was the Civil War. The northern states wanted to 
abolish the slavery. However southern states used slaves on plantations, so they declared war 
to northern states. Industrial north calling itself as Union had significant advan tage over the 
southern agriculture southern states calling itself as Confederacy. North has won the war and 
Abraham Lincoln became the president. However Abraham Lincoln was soon assassinated. 
 
The USA participated in both world wars. In the First World Wa r the USA joined France and 
the United Kingdom to help win the war against Germany. The USA was neutral in the first 
two years of Second World War. The Japanese navy  however attacked Pearl Harbour and the 
USA joined Allies in the war against Germany, Japan  and Italy.  The USA and its allies won 
the Second World War in 1945 and the USA became the world biggest economic power.  
 
In the 20th century there were many events like defending South Korea against North Korea, 
loss of war against Communist Vietnam, th e first astronaut on the Moon on Apollo 11 
mission in 1969, victory of the Cold War against Soviet Union,  two victory wars against 
Sadam Husein’s Iraq, terrorist attack on 11 September 2001 on World Trade Centre and the 
war against Taliban in Afghanistan a nd war against ISIS in Syria and Iraq. The USA is a

2 
 
member of many international organizations such as World Bank, International Monetary 
Bank, World Health Organization and leading member of NATO.  
3 Political system 
The USA is a federal constitutional repu blic. The President of the USA is head of state and 
head of government. President is elected for four years and can be one time reelected. Current 
president is Donald Trump. Congress has legislative power and Judiciary has the judicial 
power. There are two political parties called the Republicans and Democrats. The Congress is 
divided into two chambers The House of Representatives with 435 lawmakers and the Senate 
with 100 members (2 members from each state).  
4 Economy 
The USA as a world largest economy has all branches of industry like energy, automotive, 
steel making, manufacturing, textile, petrochemical, electronics and pharmaceutical. 
Agriculture is very effective and main crops are corn, wheat and cotton. Country is rich in 
coal, gold, iron, crude oil a nd gas deposits. Services are one of the main drivers of the US 
economy. The USA has very much developed hi-tech industry.  
5 National Symbols 
The US flag has 13 red and white stripes representing the original 13 colonies of the new 
nation. The blue rectangle in the upper left corner contains 50 white stars for 50 states. The 
official national symbol is brown eagle with white head. 
6 Interesting places 
Washington D.C. is the capital of the USA. The seat of the president is the White House and 
the seat of Congress is the Capitol, both buildings are in the Washington D.C. 
New York is largest city in the USA and one of the most famous cities of the USA with 
interesting places like Statue of Liberty, Stocks Exchange on Wall Street, skyscrapers like 
Empire State Building or Chrysler Building, Central Park and Brooklyn Bridge. 
Yellowstone National Park is the largest and oldest natural park in the USA. There are many 
beautiful geysers with hot springs in the area thanks to underground volcanic activity. 
Niagara Falls is beautiful water falls on US-Canadian border. 
Las Vegas is world famous  gambling city in Nevada desert and you can find many casinos 
there. 
San Francisco is a beautiful city with nearby famous Alcatraz Prison on the island in the bay 
and Golden Gate Bridge. 
Everglade Swamps are tourist attraction in Florida with beautiful water flora and fauna like 
alligators. 
Hollywood which is part of Los Angeles is world famous centre of film production. 
 
7 Holidays and Customs 
One of the most important holidays is Independence Day on 4 th July, celebrated since 1776. 
Very popular holiday is Thanksgiving Day (the fourth Thursday in November). Christmas 
Day is celebrated on 25 th December. Other holidays are Easter holidays, Halloween and 
Veterans Day.

BASIC FACTS 
− English poet, playwright and actor, widely regarded as the greatest writer in the English 
language and the world's greatest dramatist 
− He was born on 23 April 1564 in Stratford-upon-Avon 
− He died on the same day as he was born (in 1616) 
− Shakespeare’s life in London can be traced from 1592 onwards, first as an actor, then as 
a reviser and writer of plays 
− A Shakespeare Festival is held every summer in Stratford 
− Shakespeare conformed to the official state religion 
− The Bible was a constant source of inspiration to him 
 
ERA 
− He lived and worked in the 16th century in the period of the English Renaissance 
− Other known writers from this era are for example John Fletcher , John Ford, In the era 
of Renaissance in other countries the famous writers are for example Dante Alighieri, 
Francesco Petrarca or Lope de Vega 
 
EDUCATION 
− He attended the local Grammar school 
− The „grammar“ schools were the most common form of education, and they were free 
 
FAMILY 
− He was the youngest son of a glove maker John and his wife Mary 
− His father was a respected man who took part in civic life 
− He was the third of eight children, and the eldest surviving son 
− When he was eighteen he married Anne Hathaway who was 8 years older and 
already pregnant 
− They had two daughters – Susan and Judith and a son Hamnet 
− When Shakespeare was working in London, he did not leave his family for good 
− Shakespeare left a will giving all his property to his eldest daughter Susanna and his 
´second best bed´ to his wife 
 
HIS WORK

own plays and he was very successful

Romeo and Juliet 
− Romeo and Juliet is about the unhappy love and death of Romeo and Juliet, the only 
children of two powerful houses of V erona – the House of Montague and the House of 
Capulet. These two houses hate each other and Romeo Montague meets Juliet at the ball. He 
fells in love with her although he knows that she is Capulet. They love each other very much 
and ask Friar Laurence to marry them. Their love and marriage are secret and by an 
unfortunate coincidence Romeo kills Tybalt who is Juliet’s cousin. Prince of V erona sends 
Romeo to the exile outside V erona and young Juliet is forced to get married to a young 
nobleman called Paris. She asks Friar Laurence to help again and he gives her magic drops 
after which she fells asleep for several hours and looks as if she was dead. Romeo learns 
about Juliet’s death in Mantua and hurries to the Capulet´s Monument in a churchyard. He 
does no know about the trick and kills himself. Soon after the Juliet wakes up and when she 
sees Romeo dead, she kills herself to. Both Montague and Capulet Houses reconciliate only 
after the death of their beloved children.Shakespeare's standard poetic form was blank verse, 
composed in iambic pentameter 
- his verse was usually unrhymed and consisted of ten syllables to a line, spoken with a 
stress on every second syllable 
− Shakespeare combined poetic genius with a practical sense of the theatre 
− His plays have been translated into every major living language and are performed more 
often than those of any other playwright 
− His plays remain popular and are studied, performed, and reinterpreted through various 
cultural and political contexts around the world 
− Shakespeare was not revered in his lifetime, but he received a large amount of praise 
− Shakespeare made enough money to build a comfortable life 
 
INFLUENCE 
− He expanded the dramatic potential of characterisation, plot, language, and genre 
− Shakespeare influenced novelists such as Thomas Hardy, William Faulkner , and 
Charles Dickens 
− His use of English language helped shape modern English 
 
The theatre
